str2: Much, many; often.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Jewish. From Iouda; Judaean, i.e. Belonging to Jehudah.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Active - 3rd Person Plural
str2: To read, know again, know certainly, recognize, discern. From ana and ginosko; to know again, i.e. to read.
This; he, she, it.
A title, inscription. Of Latin origin; a titulus or 'title'.
Neuter of hostis as conjunction; demonstrative, that; causative, because.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Apparently a primary word; a spot, i.e. Location; figuratively, condition, opportunity; specially, a scabbard.
Where, whither, in what place. From hos and pou; what(-ever) where, i.e. At whichever spot.
Of Hebrew origin; Jesus, the name of our Lord and two other Israelites.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Passive - 3rd Person Singular
str2: From stauros; to impale on the cross; figuratively, to extinguish passion or selfishness.

parse: Verb - Imperfect Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: I am, exist. The first person singular present indicative; a prolonged form of a primary and defective verb; I exist.
Near. From a primary verb agcho; near.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
A city, the inhabitants of a city. Probably from the same as polemos, or perhaps from polus; a town.
And, even, also, namely.

parse: Verb - Imperfect Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: I am, exist. The first person singular present indicative; a prolonged form of a primary and defective verb; I exist.

parse: Verb - Perfect Participle Middle or Passive - Nominative Neuter Singular
str2: A primary verb; to 'grave', especially to write; figuratively, to describe.
In the Hebrew, or rather, in the Aramaic dialect. Adverb from Hebrais; Hebraistically or in the Jewish language.
In the Latin language. Adverb from a presumed derivative of Rhome; Romaistically, i.e. In the Latin language.
In the Greek language. Adverb from the same as Hellenistes; Hellenistically, i.e. In the Grecian language.
